content: Should we expect the c'thon in Madrid to be similar to the ones in the US? Or less people, or different tracks being in Europe?
(trying to plan and decide to go or not)
the last one in Europe was in Paris, and had similar numbers and tracks. (some US poeple not there, but more europeans there)

I believe we will be working to have the same FHIR Introduction session (Saturday AM) as we had at Connect-a-thon 14 (widely attended) followed up with a session on FHIR Testing (Test Script Resources) and Testing Tools (Test-Driven-Development - TDD) and how FHIR approach to testing can accelerate FHIR implementations while mitigating Interoperability and Conformance issues caused by implementaion flaws while interpretating standards.
Thanks Grahame & Mario
Any information about when the tracks will be announced? I'm trying to convince people I need to attend.
Announcement soliciting track proposals should be coming out today. (We're a bit behind as we've been focused on getting R3 out the door.)
@Lloyd McKenzie may i do some presentation in Madrid about my crazy ideas?
Of course! Crazy ideas are always welcome :> The question is what's the right forum. Are you there for the whole week or just at the connectathon?
@Lloyd McKenzie i would like to be for a week!
There are several possibilities - a Sat. night discussion, a presentation Sun. Q3 or Q4, some of our time Mon. am or one of the other evenings
@Lloyd McKenzie any relevant meeting
depends what the crazy ideas are
typically, yours are from all over the spectrum
Well, when I hear "session on crazy ideas" i want to join, but if I hear "all over the spectrum" then I really want to buy a ticket.

For those of you that have been staring at code all day at the connectathon, and need a small entertainment break that focuses in on the weirdness in programming languages: https://www.destroyallsoftware.com/talks/wat
my favorite lightning talk of all time, so far
And yes, the audio is important :)
very funny
could we do something similar in FHIR?
This is the one I like most: Why JavaScript sucks by Daniel Kurka. If you don't have 30 minute to watch the whole session, you can start from 7 minutes mark.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xE8tL8NdHaY&t=467s
